Subjective: Back pain radiating to right leg, thigh, foot for 1.5 weeks. Worse on right side. Unable to sleep. No relief from paracetamol and ibuprofen. Difficulty with work and exercise. No loss of strength. Slightly dull sensation on outside of lower right leg. Some tingling. No issues with sensation in riding breeches area or with urination/defecation.
Objective: No visible abnormalities in legs or back. No pain on vertebral pressure. Pain in right leg on straight leg raise. No pain in left leg on straight leg raise. Slightly dull sensation on right lower leg compared to left. No strength differences between legs. Normal reflexes.
Assessment: Lumbosacral radicular syndrome, suspected herniated disc. No signs of cauda equina syndrome.
Plan: 1. Start pregabalin for pain relief, gradually increasing dose. Monitor for side effects.
2. No driving for at least a week after starting pregabalin or if experiencing side effects.
3. Physiotherapy referral for exercises to improve back flexibility and reduce nerve compression.
4. Follow-up phone appointment in one week to assess pain relief.
5. Contact GP if symptoms worsen, loss of sensation in riding breeches area, inability to feel need to urinate/defecate, or significant loss of leg strength.
